Headline: Indiaâ€™s MSME Growth Coach | Startup Strategist | 4 MSME Turnarounds Â· 8 Startups Mentored | Author & Creator of the Diamond Systemâ„¢ | Helping Leaders Engineer Synchronicity
Comment:
Rishab , my 2 cents : 

1) Out of those dozen pitches a day , you might be binning all 

2) If a Founder of a startup or MSME knows how to visualise what you want them to do , they actually shall be on auto pilot , basically you are choosing only those pitches where the opportunity is on verge of scaling up .

3) Such Founders , I work with ,don't need investor to scale up organically , they need investors only for inorganic growth 

I do represent such clients who have answers to all you seek.

4) As a first priority , I look for Customers who are willing to invest into the business and also play customer role and use the products , services thru their own revenue models .

In a way , I do reverse due diligence, am searching for investors who have their feet into the business ground too .
Those who don't think of exit strategy only always .
A Good Founder doesn't need money alone , he actually needs valuable customers more .

Best scenario is to get Customer cum investors for my clients.
2nd priority is pure investors too .
They are equally welcome because we have all you expect .
The bottom up !
Founders who solve real problems are always Bottom Up .
#RDS

Headline: Go-To-Market & Business Development for Agentic AI, Digital Twins & Advanced Analytics | Pharma, Life Sciences, Food & Beverages | MBA from IE Business School
Comment: While I agree that many startup pitches emphasize heavily on market sizing metrics like TAM-SAM-SOM, I believe that they are not entirely useless. Like, for pre-revenue startups, the top-down market sizing can provide a theoretical maximum of the market they are targeting. If the product has already gained traction, then the bottom-up sizing makes complete sense because these startups have a clear understanding of the customer. But for others, a limited pool of early customers might not paint a clear picture, market surveys consume time and money, and startups can also present only a particular set of data, which justifies their agenda.

Couldnâ€™t agree more â€” the TAMâ€“SAMâ€“SOM slide often feels like a ritual, not a revelation.

The real signal isnâ€™t in concentric circles. Itâ€™s in customer behavior, usage patterns, and momentum. Bottom-up market sizing doesnâ€™t just show numbers â€” it shows how you think, how you build, and how you scale.

Founders who start with traction and stretch toward vision give investors a map, not a mirage. Itâ€™s not about how big the market could be â€” itâ€™s about how far your product can go, based on what itâ€™s already doing.

Thanks for calling this out. Letâ€™s make pitch decks smarter, not louder.
